content:
In response to the author's question on the forum:

The issue is kind of specific. The player's code outputs a wrong answer when both of the following conditions hold:
(a) the first decimal place is 0.
(b) the third decimal place is any of the digits from 5 to 9.

Example: 631.01852 (before rounding/formatting)
Expected (correct) output: @631.02
Actual (wrong) output: @631.20

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: It took me about 45 min to complete this puzzle.  I found the rounding a pain in python and my solution was kludged to work since .499999999 isn't .50000000.  Anyway, that's Python for you and doesn't reflect the puzzle.  It was pretty straight forward.  The reason it took me so long was because I didn't actually feel like thinking about time zones or rounding and just treated the puzzle as a reverse.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment : Fun puzzle, can be a good practice for date parsing

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Reapprove

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

Comment: Good little puzzle to learn how to parse dates

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)
With the current tests cases someone who doesn't use Decimal numbers like you will pass all tests but may fail the "With half-up rounding (even)" validator

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Halfway between a clash and a puzzle, it requires just a few lines with proper parsing.
However, this could be interesting for novice developers.

I think it would be clearer to specify the full constraints on the inputs (ranges for hours/minutes/seconds, for time and offset). Then you don't need the second note (the one with the "shenanigans") and it becomes clear that the offset is not just full hours but an valid hour/minute combination.
Apart from that, I like the problem statement!

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: top

You should switch test and validator for With half-up rounding (even) because with python the use of int(value*100+0.5)/100 to do the halfup-rouding up will pass the test but not the validator, (it cames from the 86.4 value which is converted to float 86.400000000000005684).
note taht with float int((value*100 + 0.501))/100  it will pass all tests and validators without using Decimal numbers.

Goal
* Step 2: Suggest to change "obtained" to "normalized" for clarity.

Cover picture
* Suggest to upload a cover picture for the puzzle.

Thanks.

This contribution was originally submitted as a Clash of Code challenge, but I was on the fence on whether it was too long or not. I've finally decided it was too long / complex, so made it an easy classic puzzle instead.

- "Normalized" is not quite exact. I've changed "the obtained time" to "the resulting local time", does that fit the bill?
- I've put a cover photo (image from the Swatch Internet Time video announcement), but is it actually used? When I launch the demo, the banner I see is mine, not the challenge's?
That's absolutely right, and intended! Understanding rounding algorithms is important, described in the description, and appropriate in a puzzle :-)
Please always state the reason when you approve or reject a contribution. Thanks.

I see! That's a problem I did not expect to have, I guess picking a correct rounding algorithm is harder than I thought for some ^^'

After simulating the problem, I've added the "With decimal rounding <.1" test case pair that fails on both the test and validator in this case, and fixed validator 3 so that it works even with this quirk.

Thanks for the find and detailed reporting! :-)

The problem here is not with the rounding function but the floating value of "86.4". change your code and use float("86.4") instead of Decimal("86.4") to try it.

Having an algorithm which passes all tests but fails on  one validator because of that  only proves tests aren't good enough.
Oh, I see what you mean. I don't have my scripts from that time unfortunately, but I've inverted both the test and the validator to ensure that it fails on the test.

I suggested "normalized" because you use the term "normalize" in step 1 ðŸ˜‰

The cover picture shows on the cover page only (i.e. this page), not the IDE/demo page.

Ah, you're right. Did the following:

- Switched to "Biel time" instead ("local time" was too general, technically the original time is also local time)
- Added an example to make it extra clear.
- Revamped the formatting, added a note about rounding.
- Added a set of tests to prevent half-odd rounding being used, which also checks that we do calculations in a decimal system instead of IEEE 754 as an added bonus! (had to fix my code to use decimal calculations, so that's a good sign)

How about now? :)
That's definitely better!
